title: Quiz 6: Surgery Essays (2016-2017)
description: Interactive revision of Short and Long Essay questions from June 2017 and July 2016 Surgery papers. Covers Orthopaedics, General Surgery, and Trauma cases.

questions.question: Regarding Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma), select the correct Clinical Features and X-ray findings. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Clinical: Deep bone pain, worse at night

questions.explanation: Osteosarcoma typically presents with night pain and a mass. X-ray shows Sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle. Onion-peel is seen in Ewing's Sarcoma.
questions.hint: Think about the sun rising over a triangle.

questions.question: Select the valid indications for performing a Thyroidectomy.

options.text: Toxic Goiter refractory to medical treatment

questions.explanation: Thyroidectomy is indicated for cancer, compression, cosmetic concerns, or failed medical management of thyrotoxicosis.
questions.hint: Reasons to remove: Cancer, Compression, Cosmetics, Control.

questions.question:
Calculate the fluid requirements for an 18-year-old male (50 kg) with 30% TBSA burns using the Parkland Formula (4ml x kg x %TBSA).

Total 24-hour volume: ___BLANK___ ml.
Volume for FIRST 8 hours: ___BLANK___ ml.
questions.explanation: Total = 4 x 50 x 30 = 6,000 ml. First 8 hours = 50% of total = 3,000 ml.
questions.hint: 4 times weight times percentage. Divide by 2 for the first 8 hours.

questions.question: Which of the following are clinical features of Posterior Hip Dislocation? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Posterior dislocation presents with the limb Shortened, Adducted, and Internally Rotated (SAIR). Anterior dislocation is Abducted and Externally Rotated.
questions.hint: Think of a person trying to hide their modesty (legs closed/in).

questions.question: Match the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) response to its correct score.
questions.explanation: E(4), V(5), M(6). Review the GCS table.
questions.hint: Eyes max 4, Verbal max 5, Motor max 6.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for male urethral catheterization in the correct order.

items.text: Instill lignocaine gel and hold meatus closed for 3-5 mins
Insert catheter holding penis perpendicular (90 degrees)
Advance to bifurcation (Y-junction) after urine flows
Inflate balloon and gently pull back

questions.explanation: Cleaning -> Anaesthesia/Lubrication -> Insertion -> Placement Confirmation -> Retention.

questions.question: Case Study: 70yo male, progressive painless jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, pruritus. Select the correct diagnosis and relevant investigations.

richContent.content:
Patient Profile: 70-year-old man.
History: 2 weeks progressive yellowish eyes, itching, dark urine.
Exam: Deeply jaundiced, scratch marks. Abdomen unremarkable.

options.text: Diagnosis: Obstructive Jaundice (likely CA Head of Pancreas)
Clotting Profile (INR) - check for Vit K deficiency
Imaging: Abdominal Ultrasound or CT Scan

questions.explanation: Painless progressive jaundice in an elderly patient is highly suspicious for malignancy (Pancreatic CA/Cholangiocarcinoma) causing obstruction.
questions.hint: Old man, painless jaundice = Cancer until proven otherwise.

questions.question: Case Study: 10yo boy, 4 days history of swollen, hot, painful knee + fever (39Â°C). Select the correct Diagnosis and Treatment.
questions.explanation: Acute hot swollen joint with fever is Septic Arthritis. It is an orthopedic emergency requiring drainage to save the cartilage.
questions.hint: Pus in joint = Wash it out.

questions.question: Regarding Colles' Fracture, select the correct descriptions and complications.

options.text: Distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement
Complication: Rupture of Extensor Pollicis Longus (EPL)

questions.explanation: Colles' = Dorsal displacement (Dinner Fork). Smith's = Volar displacement (Garden Spade). EPL rupture is a specific late complication.
questions.hint: Fall on outstretched hand -> Dorsal shift.

questions.question: Select five common differential diagnoses for Scrotal Swellings.
questions.explanation: Femoral hernias appear below the inguinal ligament and rarely present as scrotal swellings.
questions.hint: Think about what's in the scrotum.

questions.question: Match the Gustilo-Anderson classification of Open Fractures.

pairs.right: Extensive loss, periosteal stripping, needs flap

questions.explanation: Classification guides management: Type I/II often closed primarily/delayed; Type III require aggressive debridement and often flaps (IIIB) or vascular repair (IIIC).
questions.hint: I is small, III is big, C is circulation.

questions.question: Select the correct complications of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).
questions.explanation: BPH causes obstruction, stasis (stones, UTI), and back pressure (hydronephrosis). Torsion is unrelated.
